head.title: Down the Diesel Road: Problem or Solution?

hedline.hl1: Down the Diesel Road: Problem or Solution?

abstract.p: Union of Concerned Scientists aide Michelle Robinson letter on May 27 article defends tight emissions standards that preclude widespread sales of diesel cars

block.p: The potential of diesel technology to reduce global warming pollution and deliver more efficient automobiles should not be overestimated (front page, May 27). The tight emissions standards that preclude widespread sales of diesel cars and trucks have ample justification in the growing evidence of health risks from diesel exhaust that have been identified by public health groups and agencies.

The potential of diesel technology to reduce global warming pollution and deliver more efficient automobiles should not be overestimated (front page, May 27). The tight emissions standards that preclude widespread sales of diesel cars and trucks have ample justification in the growing evidence of health risks from diesel exhaust that have been identified by public health groups and agencies.

Protecting the public from the health risks will reduce the fuel-efficiency potential of diesel vehicles. Engine modifications and after-treatment devices limit how far the vehicle can travel on a gallon of fuel. And without an increase in fuel-economy standards, automakers may use the efficiency advantages of diesel to offset growing sales of heavier, gas-guzzling vehicles.
The writer is the senior policy adviser of the clean vehicles program, Union of Concerned Scientists.
